body: EVER feel duck confit isn't quite rich enough? Get ready for rillettes, a positively creamy blend of meat, fat and spice. Pork (or duck, goose or a rich fish like salmon or cod) is slowly poached in fat, then shredded and pounded, with salt, pepper and perhaps a little more fat added to render the mixture luxuriantly spreadable. In France,
title: TEMPTATION; A Feast of Fat in the French Style

title: PUBLIC LIVES; Entrepreneur Takes Black-Oriented Site Out of Red

body: I PROPOSE that someone should make a feature-length, general-release film about knitting. Right here. In New York. Not some movie about frail, bespectacled ladies and Orlon afghans. title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: URBAN STUDIES/KNITTING; The Raveled Sleeve of Care, and All That

body: The city's property tax rate, frozen for a decade, will rise by 18 percent on Jan. 1 under an agreement announced yesterday between the Bloomberg administration and City Council leaders. ''It's a painful measure,'' the Council speaker, Gifford Miller, said in announcing the agreement in the Red Room at City Hall shortly after 4:30 p.m. The deal
title: CITY BUDGET DEAL INCLUDES 18% RISE IN PROPERTY TAXES

body: TIME was, you could stroll into a smoke-steeped bookstore on the Lower East Side, gamble a few bucks on a new novella by a budding writer-slash-anarchist who lived down the block, wander into the murky bar next door, and eavesdrop on that same writer trying to pry beer money from his editor. Those were the heady final years of the 20th century,
title: URBAN TACTICS; Latest Exit to Brooklyn

body: Legacy of Hell His name was Robert Knox Sneden (1832-1918). He died unmarried and childless. ''I leave no posterity, but a good war record,'' he once said. Sneden's record consisted of more than his Civil War service with the 40th New York Volunteers as a map maker, witnessing the Peninsula Campaign, the Seven Days and the second Battle of Bull Run
title: FOOTLIGHTS

body: It is the undisputed king of the Brooklyn skyline, the most populous borough's only widely recognized piece of architecture that is not a roller coaster. Its gigantic clock tower looms up in half the apartment windows in town, a communal wristwatch that sometimes seems to be watching you. It is the Williamsburgh Savings Bank building, Brooklyn's
title: MY BROOKLYN; A Tower of Dentists Wears a Golden Crown

body: Of the 18 Civil Court judgeships up for election in New York City this November, only six are being contested in next week's Democratic primary. As a practical matter, that means the remaining dozen seats will be filled by men and women deeply beholden to the party pols who gave them a berth on the Democratic line and a virtually uncontested ride
title: For Civil Court in Brooklyn

body: One of the first results of a recent change in zoning in downtown Brooklyn is beginning to take shape at 53 Boerum Place, where construction began last month on an 11-story building that will have 99 market-rate rental apartments. The nine-block area affected by the rezoning is on the edge of downtown Brooklyn and connects it to the Brooklyn
title: Residential Real Estate; First, the Zoning Change; Next, the Apartments

title: Here's Your Change; Give It Back; Those Countertop Jars Strain the Etiquette of Tipping

body: As former City Councilman Angel Rodriguez of Brooklyn pleaded guilty yesterday in a federal bribery case, the race to succeed him was already taking shape. A wide range of contenders have emerged in the district represented by Mr. Rodriguez for the last four years. Some had formed official campaign committees to run for the seat months before Mr.
title: Race Is On for Seat of Ex-Councilman Guilty in Bribery Case

body: City Councilman Angel Rodriguez of Brooklyn resigned his post yesterday as he prepared to plead guilty to federal charges that he took bribes in exchange for throwing his support behind a supermarket project in Red Hook that he had once opposed. Mr. Rodriguez, who was a serious contender to become speaker of the City Council earlier this year, now
title: Councilman in Bribery Case Resigns on Eve of Guilty Plea

body: The city with the largest American Indian population, according to the 2000 Census, is not Phoenix. Not Los Angeles. It is New York City. The news is a surprise even to some Indians living in the city. ''You're kidding, right?'' said Rosemary Richmond, the director of the American Indian Community House in Manhattan. The census counted 41,289
title: Native New Yorkers (The Original Kind); American Indians of Many Tribes Work to Preserve Identity in City

body: For Janice Combs, the American dream has always been a family affair. When her son, Sean Combs (lately known as P. Diddy), was climbing the charts as a rap artist and starting out as an entrepreneur, she worked as his stylist and helped manage his restaurant, Justin's. But at Mama Duke Southern Cuisine, a small shop in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, that
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BOERUM HILL; A Whole Lot Of Soul, And a Little Hip-Hop, Too

body: The surprising drop in median income in New York City that has puzzled demographers studying the results of the 2000 census appears to be traceable in large part to immigration, according to new census data that show income declines concentrated heavily in neighborhoods in the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens that have become magnets for new arrivals.
title: Immigration Cut Into Income In New York, Census Finds

body: In the last five years, the so-called rebirth of Smith Street has been, by all accounts, a smashing economic success. But as a sleepier, more old-fashioned way of life gives way to a flourishing nightclub and restaurant scene, the strip has discovered a big-city woe: noise ordinances and the stiff penalties that come with them. Garrett McConnell,
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BOERUM HILL; Bring In da Noise, And You'll Be Fined

body: Detectives in Brooklyn yesterday arrested a suspect who had escaped from police custody in March, in the second arrest of an escapee in two days, the authorities said. The man, Larry Nelson, 32, was arrested at about 7:30 a.m. in an apartment at 272 Wyckoff Street in Boerum Hill, the police said. Mr. Nelson, of 2041 Pacific Street, escaped on March
title: One Who Got Away Is Caught in Brooklyn

body: LEGEND has it that much of Manhattan was built by Mohawk ironworkers, and legend, in this case, is right. The Empire State Building. Rockefeller Center. The World Trade Center. title: Blocks; In Downtown Brooklyn, Too Tall Suddenly Fits

title: Restaurants On Other Rows Are Suffering

body: To the Editor: In ''New York's Best Espresso?'' (May 15), William Grimes accurately and sadly describes why New Yorkers just can't get a passable espresso: it's the people! A few summers ago, I was living in Brooklyn and stumbled upon a new cafe on the edge of Boerum Hill. It not only served New York's best espresso, but the best espresso I had
title: The Espresso Crusade

body: To the Editor: In your article on school choice, ''Pick One'' (April 28), you focused on largely English-speaking, white, upper-middle-class neighborhoods, Cobble Hill and Boerum Hill, Brooklyn. We live in a more economically and ethnically diverse neighborhood, Ditmas Park, and faced the choice of public or private for our son. Many home-buyers
title: Public, Private: What's a Parent to Do?

body: A CENTURY ago, Carroll Gardens was a working-class neighborhood in Brooklyn, home to thousands of Irish immigrants. In the decades before World War II, the Irish moved out and first-generation Italians moved in. The neighborhood kept its Italian-American character for decades and to a large degree retains it still. But in recent years a new group
title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Carroll Gardens; Area of Gardens and 19th-Century Charm

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BOERUM HILL; A Tale of Requited Love: A Man and a Pipe Organ

body: NOT so long ago, Clinton Street on the Lower East Side was a grim, grafitti-ridden streetscape. By night, bags of heroin were sold by brand name, while prostitutes peddled their wares nearby. Things looked even worse, if possible, under daylight, which shone on Clinton Street like fluorescent lights on a hangover. In a scant few years, though,
title: And to Think That I Ate It on Clinton Street

body: WITH Manhattan's co-op and condominium market returning to a rolling boil, a number of real estate brokers and executives say the city is rife with -- can you believe it? -- bad behavior among agents, which they say hurts the buyers and sellers alike. Disgruntled brokers say increasingly competitive colleagues are withholding, or pocketing, their
title: TURF; Agents Play Hide-and-Seek As the Market Quickens

title: PUBLIC LIVES; A Union Maid? Actually a Nanny, Organizing

body: Yesterday, there was the Albee Square Mall, the glass-enclosed retail future of Downtown Brooklyn. Today, after two decades spent either treading water or sinking, the mall, now the Gallery at MetroTech, stands drab and a bit forlorn. But tomorrow, the mall's new owner says, a golden castle will rise above the honky-tonk bustle of the Fulton Street
title: Grand Plans For a Mall That's Heard It All Before

title: POSTINGS: Mixed-Use Project on Atlantic Avenue; $90 Million Plan For Brooklyn

body: A Brooklyn councilman who was recently a contender for City Council speaker was charged yesterday with demanding a $1.5 million break on a real estate deal from a developer in exchange for supporting the multimillion-dollar renovation of a waterfront warehouse in his district. The councilman, Angel Rodriguez, a Democrat, represents the Red Hook
title: Brooklyn Councilman Is Charged in an Extortion Scheme

body: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg went to Brooklyn yesterday to try to calm some of the emotions stirred up by the latest twists in the Abner Louima case. The mayor began his day with a trip to the scene of the crime: the 70th Precinct station house in Flatbush, where Mr. Louima, a Haitian immigrant, was tortured by at least one police officer in 1997. At
title: Mayoral Visits Seek to Heal Old Wounds of Louima Case

body: THERE is a spot in the lower jaw where the back of the front teeth and the gum merge. Only by tucking the tip of my tongue into that spot can I achieve the proper inflection to pronounce Tuk Tuk, the name of an appealing new Thai restaurant on Smith Street in Brooklyn. title: $25 AND UNDER; Thai Food in Its Hot, Spicy and Garlicky Glory
